p: In-vitro studies suggested that A. muricata leaf extract is selectively toxic against cancerous cells without harmful effects on the healthy cells [ 11, 28, 29]. Additionally, the stimulation of macrophages may facilitate the release of different types of cytokines in the peritoneal cavity which could play a role in tumour cell killing [ 30]. Also, bioactive compounds such as Annonaceous acetogenins, muricoreacin, and murihexocin C present in the leaves of A. muricata are known to show their antitumourigenic activity through the cytotoxic mode of action [ 31, 32].
